Question Text: Which of the following properties are characteristics of virtual networks (but not necessarily characteristics of SDN). Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Separates the data and control plane.
b. Refactors network control so that network behavior is controlled from a single logically centralized controller.
c. Separates logical and physical networks.
d. Often deployed in data center networks to allow multiple tenants to share physical network infrastructure.
e. Abstracts the details of the physical network.
LLM Explanation: Virtual networks (network virtualization) create logical networks decoupled from the underlying physical topology: they separate the logical and physical networks (c), abstract the details of the physical network (e), and are commonly used in data centers to support multi-tenancy and sharing of the same physical infrastructure (d). In contrast, separating data and control planes (a) and centralizing control in a single logically centralized controller (b) are hallmarks of SDN architectures and are not required properties of virtual networks.

Question Text: Which of the following are possible ways of creating virtual links in a virtual network? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. A wide-area tunnel, whereby an IP packet is encapsulated in an MPLS tunnel by attaching an MPLS header to the packet.
b. Longest-prefix match forwarding on an IP router.
c. A wide-area tunnel, whereby an Ethernet packet sent between two virtual machines is encapsulated in an IP packet.
d. VLAN switching based on a VLAN tag.
e. Pairs of virtual Ethernet interfaces, where one end of the Ethernet interface pair resides in the virtual environment, and the other resides in the root namespace on the host machine.
LLM Explanation: a) Yes — MPLS can be used as a wide‑area tunnel (label‑switched path) that encapsulates/labels IP packets to create a virtual link across a provider network. c) Yes — Ethernet‑over‑IP tunnels (e.g., VXLAN, GRE/L2TPv3 carrying L2 frames) encapsulate Ethernet frames in IP, creating L2 virtual links across an IP network. d) Yes — VLAN tagging (802.1Q) implements virtual LANs; switching based on the VLAN tag creates virtual links between ports in the same VLAN. e) Yes — veth (virtual Ethernet) interface pairs (one end in a container/VM namespace, the peer in the host/root namespace) are a common local virtual link technology. b) No — longest‑prefix match is an IP forwarding/routing decision algorithm, not a mechanism that creates a virtual link or overlay; it selects routes over existing links rather than instantiating virtual links itself.

Question Text: Which of the following are true of the Mininet network emulator? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. It requires running OpenFlow-capable switches.
b. It is difficult to use it to route traffic for real services.
c. Mininet only allows users to create three types of topologies: linear, tree, and single-switch topologies.
d. It can create an emulation that runs across multiple physically distributed nodes.
e. All of the hosts in the topology must run the same underlying operating system.
LLM Explanation: d: True — Mininet can be extended to run emulations across multiple physical machines (there is built-in support and community projects/tools such as Distributed Mininet and MaxiNet for distributed execution). e: True — on a single-machine Mininet deployment hosts are Linux network namespaces (lightweight processes) sharing the same kernel/underlying OS, so Mininet-hosts run the same OS. a, b, c are false: Mininet does not require OpenFlow-only switches (it can use different switch implementations), it is straightforward to run real services inside Mininet hosts, and it supports arbitrary/custom topologies (not limited to only linear, tree, and single-switch).
URLs: ['https://mininet.org/', 'https://github.com/mininet/mininet/wiki/Introduction', 'https://github.com/mininet/mininet/wiki/Distributed-Mininet', 'https://maxinet.github.io/', 'Lantz, B., Heller, B., & McKeown, N. (2010). Mininet: An Instant Virtual Network on your Laptop (HotNets).']

Question Text: What are the benefits of emulation as opposed to, say, simulation? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. An emulation will complete faster than a simulation.
b. An emulator makes it possible to "port" experiments from one machine to another.
c. An emulator allows the experimenter run real software on each of the nodes in the emulation.
d. An emulation is easier to debug than a simulation.
e. Every run of the emulator will yield exactly the same results, resulting in reproducible experiments.
LLM Explanation: Emulation runs real software stacks on virtualized or containerized nodes and mirrors host interfaces, so experiments can be ported between machines and you can run unmodified real software on each emulated node (benefits b and c). Emulation does not inherently complete faster than simulation (a is not generally true), is not necessarily easier to debug than simulation (d is not generally true; real-system complexity can make debugging harder), and does not guarantee bitwise-identical runs each time (e is false because timing, scheduling and external interactions can introduce nondeterminism).

Question Text: Which of the following are possible in Mininet? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Measuring the latency between a host in San Francisco and a host in Los Angeles.
b. Assigning custom IP addresses to each node in the topology.
c. Assigning IP addresses to each node in the topology using a DHCP server.
d. Running performance measurement tools (e.g., iperf, wget) between nodes.
e. "Shaping" a link between two nodes to a particular traffic rate.
LLM Explanation: b: True — Mininet hosts are configurable; you can assign custom IPs when creating hosts or via the CLI (e.g., h1.setIP or h1 ifconfig). c: True — Mininet hosts are real network namespaces and can use DHCP (examples include the mininet/examples/dhcp.py); you can run a DHCP server or dhclient within the emulation to obtain addresses. d: True — Mininet runs real user-space programs in host namespaces, so tools like iperf, wget, ping, etc., can be executed between nodes. e: True — Mininet supports traffic shaping on links (e.g., TCLink or link parameters like bw, delay, loss) using Linux tc to constrain bandwidth/latency. a: Not (generally) true — Mininet is a local network emulator; it cannot directly measure the real-world latency between two geographically separated real hosts (San Francisco vs Los Angeles) unless you actually run Mininet instances on machines located in those cities and connect them over the Internet. You can, however, emulate such geographic latency by configuring link delay parameters.

Question Text: Which of the following functions does FlowVisor enable? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy different load balancing applications for all traffic between the same source-destination pair.
b. Allowing two controllers to control traffic on distinct VLANs.
c. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy different Web load balancing applications for port 80 traffic.
d. Allowing two different researchers to implement and deploy control mechanisms for two distinct applications.
e. Allowing one controller to control TCP traffic and one controller to control UDP traffic.
LLM Explanation: FlowVisor is an OpenFlow hypervisor that slices the network by flowspace and delegates disjoint flowspaces to different controllers. It supports isolation by header fields (e.g., VLAN IDs, IP/TCP/UDP fields), so controllers can each manage distinct VLANs (b), different applications that operate on different flowspaces (d), or split by protocol (TCP vs UDP) (e). It does not permit multiple controllers to concurrently control the exact same flowspace (so two different researchers cannot both control all traffic for the same src–dst pair (a) or both control port-80 traffic (c)).

Question Text: Which of the following are stated applications of the Nicira Network Virtualization Platform? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Easier transition to IPv6 in data-center networks.
b. Creating more than 1024 virtual networks, as opposed to the alternative of using VLAN tags.
c. Allowing experimental protocols to coincide with a production network.
d. Central management of security policies.
e. Dynamic workload placement in multi-tenant data centers.
LLM Explanation: Nicira's Network Virtualization Platform (NVP, now part of VMware NSX) explicitly advertises use-cases that come from decoupling logical networks from the physical: enabling easy multi‑tenant isolation beyond VLAN limits (so you can create many more virtual networks than VLAN tags allow) (b); letting experimental or custom protocols run in virtual networks alongside production traffic without affecting the underlay (c); centralized policy/security management applied to virtual networks (d); and support for dynamic workload/VM placement in multi‑tenant data centers (e). Because addressing is part of the virtual network abstraction, NVP also lowers the operational friction for address scheme changes and migrations (including IPv6 transition), so easing IPv6 transition is a stated application (a).

Question Text: Select the statement that is most true about the relationship between network virtualization and SDNs.
Choices:
a. Network virtualization is a potential enabler for software-defined networks, since the separation of data and control planes first requires the creation of a logical network.
b. Software-defined networking is a potential enabler for virtual networks, since separation of data and control planes makes it easier to manage a logical network topology.
c. Network virtualization is a new concept introduced by Amazon, Nicira, and industry players; it only made sense to talk about network virtualization once central SDN controllers existed.
d. Network virtualization and software-defined networking each enable the other: SDN cannot exist without network virtualization, and network virtualization cannot exist without SDN.
LLM Explanation: SDN (centralized, programmatic separation of control and data planes) makes it far easier to create and manage logical/virtual networks (overlays, tenant slices, virtual topologies). Thus SDN is a strong enabler for network virtualization. The converse claims (that virtualization must precede SDN or that each cannot exist without the other) are incorrect: network virtualization techniques (VLANs, VPNs, overlays, MPLS) predate or can exist without SDN, and SDN can be used even without full network virtualization.
